symptoms: Primary chancres appear on: Men: Penis Anus Rectum Women: Vulva Cervix Perineum Both: Lips Tongue Buccal mucosa Tonsils Fingers A red papule appears and quickly erodes into a painless ulcer with a lacquer-like base and hard walls. It does not bleed. When scratched, it exudes a clear serum. A red areola may surround the lesion.
Secondary Stage: Skin rashes Some people have lesions affecting other tissues and organs including: Eyes Bones Joints Kidneys Liver Spleen

Constitutional symptoms may also be present such as: Persistent headache Malaise Anorexia Nausea Aching bones Fever Insomnia Jaundice Neck stiffness Alopecia in patches Lesions affecting the mucous membranes often become eroded forming grayish-white circular patches with a red areola which are usually found on the: Mouth Palate Pharynx Larynx Penis Vulva Anal canal Rectum
